topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5400dab36368720dae6a0100#post_5400dab36368720dae6a0100

Here's a story for ya: I was at the Bronx Zoo with my family when my mother wanted to use the toilet. She goes into the bathroom. There's two small children zipping around, and their mother is completely ignoring them, on her phone or something. My mom comes out of her stall when she hears "I dare you to lick the toilet". And one of the boys is actually on his hands and knees, _about to do it._ My mom looks at him, and simply says "don't." The mother of these kids turns around and says "Don't tell my children what to do!" My mom, of course, responds with "Your children were about to lick a _toilet._" What's the other woman's response? "Who do you think you are?"

People are ingrates.


"@Shadow_the_Hedgehog":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5400dadf6368720269330000#post_5400dadf6368720269330000

Oh, yeah. Kids shouldn't be playing TF2, GTA, or really anything above a T rating.

topics.body:
"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5400dacb636872124b0e0000#post_5400dacb636872124b0e0000

If an adult puts their hands on my child, I'm going to be slightly upset unless there's a good reason (example, he's about to jump off a bridge). You shouldn't lay your hands on someone else's kids. But if my kids are about to hurt themselves and for whatever reason I don't notice, hell yeah, I want someone to stop them with a stern word.

topics.body:
"@Shadow_the_Hedgehog":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5400dbfa6368721f5b6d0100#post_5400dbfa6368721f5b6d0100
My mom always got me m rated games as a kid because she knew I could separate fiction from reality and I could handle fictional violence. 
Plus I grew up in the 90's. Every other action figure was either covered in blood and organs or had big chunks of skin missing with visible muscle tissue and exposed bone. 

Now, I'm not saying every kid should go play rapemurder simulator 98 but rather their parents should understand what sort of media they're giving their child and whether or not their child can handle it. 

Really I think it comes down to the radical idea that parents should understand their child instead of plopping them down I front of a tv to shut them up.
